00034 
00074 /* Preprocessor directive that conditionally compiles the code that uses the weakly-linked MessageUI.Framework.
00075  This framework is required if you want to include the ability to share activities with email or sms.  By default
00076  the JRENGAGE_INCLUDE_EMAIL_SMS flag should always be set to "1", which can cause errors with the linker if the
00077  framework isn't included, but I figured most apps would want the email and sms sharing ability.  If you don't want
00078  to add the MessageUI.Framework to one or more of your apps that use the JREngage library, you don't have to change
00079  this value to "0" (which could cause merging issues if I make changes later).
00080 
00081  Instead, if you want to override this setting, you need to add the preprocessor flag "OVERRIDE_INCLUDE_EMAIL_SMS"
00082  to your target's GCC_PREPROCESSOR_DEFINITIONS build setting (also listed as "Preprocessor Macros" under the
00083  "GCC 4.2 - Preprocessing" heading). */
00084 #ifndef OVERRIDE_INCLUDE_EMAIL_SMS
00085 #define JRENGAGE_INCLUDE_EMAIL_SMS 1
00086 #endif
00087

00445 
00447 // * Use this function to begin authentication.  The JREngage library will pop up a modal dialog,
00448 // * configured with the given custom interface, possibly skipping the user landing page,
00449 // * and take the user through the sign-in process.
00450 // *
00451 // * @param customInterfaceOverrides
00452 // *   A dictionary of objects and properties, indexed by the set of
00453 // *   \link customInterface pre-defined custom interface keys\endlink,
00454 // *   to be used by the library to customize the look and feel of the user
00455 // *   interface and/or add a native login experience
00456 // *
00457 // * @param skipReturningUserLandingPage
00458 // *   Prevents the dialog from opening to the returning-user landing page when \c YES.  That is, the
00459 // *   dialog will always open straight to the list of providers.  The dialog falls back to the default
00460 // *   behavior when \c NO
00461 // *
00462 // * @note
00463 // * Any values specified in the \e customInterfaceOverrides dictionary will override the corresponding
00464 // * values specified the dictionary passed into the setCustomInterfaceDefaults:() method.
00465 // *
00466 // * @note
00467 // * If you always want to force the user to re=enter his/her credentials, pass \c true to the method
00468 // * setAlwaysForceReauthentication().
00469 // **/
00470 //- (void)showAuthenticationDialogWithCustomInterfaceOverrides:(NSDictionary*)customInterfaceOverrides
00471 //                            skippingReturningUserLandingPage:(BOOL)skipReturningUserLandingPage;
00472 //
00474 // * Use this function to begin authentication.  The JREngage library will pop up a modal dialog and
00475 // * take the user through the sign-in process.
00476 // *
00477 // * @param skipReturningUserLandingPage
00478 // *   Prevents the dialog from opening to the returning-user landing page when \c YES.  That is, the
00479 // *   dialog will always open straight to the list of providers.  The dialog falls back to the default
00480 // *   behavior when \c NO
00481 // *
00482 // * @note
00483 // * If you always want to force the user to re=enter his/her credentials, pass \c true to the method
00484 // * setAlwaysForceReauthentication().
00485 // **/
00486 //- (void)showAuthenticationDialogSkippingReturningUserLandingPage:(BOOL)skipReturningUserLandingPage;
00487 
00489 // *
00490 // **/
00491 //- (void)showAuthenticationDialogWithForcedReauthenticationOnLastUsedProvider;
00492 
00502 - (void)showSocialPublishingDialogWithActivity:(JRActivityObject*)activity;
